position.marginalia_text: Cicero, et pla[e]riq[ue] omnes Romani pro Regulo: Augustinus, et Calcagninus contra Regulum. Optimi theologi, iurisconsulti, Politici pro Augustino. Natura pro se: ars pro natura. Multi scrupuli nimis arguti contra se: plures argutia[e] nimis scrupulosa[e] contra naturam, et artem. Non amo nimiùm diligentes, inquit ille: nec Socrates apud Platonem vult esse nimiùm iustus. Et hîc, et alibi, crede mihi, sapere est, non nimiùm sapere.

marginalia.translation: Cicero and nearly all Romans were for Regulus, Augustine and Calcagninus were against Regulus. The best theologians, jurists and politicians are for Augustine. Nature is for itself, art is for nature. Many overly clever worries are against themselves; still more clever, overly painstaking, arguments are against nature and art. "I do not like those who are too careful", he said, and in Plato Socrates does not want to be overly just. Believe me, both here and elsewhere it is wise not to be too wise.
The splendid rewards of such great victories.
The very famous trustworthiness of Marcus Regulus.

book.title: Disquisitiones aliquot in libros Officiorum Ciceronis

position.marginalia_text: = Quòd in ea virtute, qua Regulus Catone pra[e]stantior fuit, multò magis emineant Christiani. Insigne caput Augustini, libro 1. de Civitate dei. Quale etiam eodem libro c. 15. Duo de Marci Reguli fide memorabilia capita. Quanta[e] etiam illa[e] Augustini ad historiam Punicam disputationes? Quanta[e] clades Romanos sub bellis Punicis triverint: frustra Deorum pra[e]sidiis expetitis. l. 3. c. 18 de Civitate Dei. De afflictione belli Punici secundi, qua vires vtriusque partis consumpta[e] sunt. c. 19. De exitio Saguntinoru[m], quibus propter Romanoru[m] amicitiam pereuntibus, Dij Rom. auxilium non tulerunt. c. 20. Quàm ingrata fuerit Romana Civitas Scipioni liberatori suo; et in quibus moribus egerit, quando eam Sallustius, optimam fuisse describit. c. 21. Tempora, exitusque bellorum ex Dei pendere iudicio. l. 5. c. 22. vbi expressè tam de bello Punico primo, et secundo, quam de Samnitico, de Mithridatico, de aliis Romanoru[m] bellis. Et quot annos duraverint. Punicum primu[m] 23: secundu[m] 18: Samniticum fermè 50: Mithridaticum 40. Punicu[m] tertium incredibili celeritate: ut pirataru[m]: gladiatoru[m]: Italicum paucis annis. Caput valdè notabile. Observandis etiam L. Vivis animadversionibus.

marginalia.translation: In Cicero’s De officiis Caelius Calcaginus injures Regulus’ credibility. A sharp disputation, worthy of a fine philosopher, jurist, theologian. That in that virtue in which Regulus excelled Cato the Christians are more eminent still. A remarkable chapter of Augustine’s City of God, bk. 1 [chapter 24]. And similar also in the same book, ch. 15. Two memorable chapters about the trustworthiness of Marcus Regulus. How great are also those discussions about the Punic history? How great were the disasters suffered by the Romans during the Punic Wars, which were not lessened by the protection sought from the gods: City of God, bk. 3, ch. 18. Of the affliction of the second Punic War, by which the strength of both sides was consumed: ch. 19; Of the destruction of the Saguntines, who perished because of their friendship for Rome, yet received no help from the Roman gods, ch. 20; Of the ingratitude of the city of Rome to her deliverer Scipio, and of her morals during the period which Sallust describes as the best, ch. 21; That the durations and outcomes of wars depend upon the judgment of God, bk.5, ch. 22, where [he writes] with precision about the both the first and second Punic wars, as well the Samnite war, the Mithridatic, and other wars of the Romans, and how many years they lasted. The first Punic war 23; the second 18; the Samnite war almost 50, the Mithridatic one 40. The third Punic war went with incredible speed, just like the Italic war of the Pirates and gladiators took a few years. A very striking chapter, with annotations by L. Vives that also deserve close attention.
